title: 114_s1885
content: The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands the definition of homeless veterans for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. It also establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans receiving the most healthcare from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for covered veterans enrolled in the homeless registry and annual patient enrollment system. The program will be carried out at six locations, including cities with the largest homeless veteran populations and suburban or rural settings. The program established by the "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" will provide intensive case management interventions to covered veterans at six locations, including suburban or rural settings. The Secretary will select locations with a high degree of interaction between the Department and community organizations providing housing and social services for veterans. Intensive case management interventions will be provided to at least 20 covered veterans at each location to assist with gaining and maintaining access to housing and services. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" program will provide assistance to covered veterans in gaining and maintaining access to housing and services, including benefits and healthcare improvements. A clerical amendment will be made to the table of sections in the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will start the intensive case management program by September 1, 2016. A report on the program's assessments, including types of interventions, housing status, and employment status of veterans, must be submitted by December 1, 2018 to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The intensive case management program for veterans includes assessing employment status before and after interventions, tracking use of VA health services, and costs incurred. The program aims to provide interventions in various locations. The costs incurred by the Department for the intensive case management program for veterans, including provision of health care services, are estimated based on locations where interventions were provided. Program to improve retention of housing by formerly homeless veterans and veterans at risk of becoming homeless. The Secretary is required to implement a program providing case management services to help formerly homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness retain housing. Grants will be awarded to organizations with a proven ability to offer these services, with priority given to those experienced in transitional housing. The Secretary prioritizes organizations providing transitional housing services, giving extra priority to those that voluntarily convert facilities to permanent housing meeting quality standards. Conversion of facilities funded by grants is considered in line with Department needs. The Secretary prioritizes organizations converting facilities to permanent housing meeting quality standards funded by grants, ensuring compliance with Department needs. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to prescribe regulations for a program aimed at improving housing retention for homeless veterans. A report assessing the program's effectiveness in helping veterans retain permanent housing must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by June 1, 2019. The report should include data on the percentage of veterans who received case management services and were able to retain permanent housing by the end of the pilot program. The report assessing the program's effectiveness should include data on veterans retaining permanent housing, veterans not in permanent housing at the end of the program, use of housing assistance by veterans, and the employment status of veterans before and after receiving case management services. Expansion of housing assistance program for veterans by the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2041 of title 38 to expand housing assistance for homeless veterans, veterans at risk of homelessness, and very low-income veteran families. This includes acquiring shelter, transitioning to permanent housing, and maintaining occupancy. This includes acquiring shelter, transitioning to permanent housing, and maintaining occupancy. Additionally, the amendments aim to ensure that veterans receiving housing also receive referrals for entitled benefits and services. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2041 of title 38 to expand housing assistance for veterans and families described in paragraph (1). The table of sections in chapter 20 is also being amended accordingly. The Department of Veterans Affairs is expanding housing assistance for homeless veterans, veterans in temporary housing, and very low-income veteran families. They are collaborating with various entities to increase the availability of housing for veterans. Additionally, a National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans is being established. The Department of Veterans Affairs is establishing the National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to conduct research, assess program effectiveness, and disseminate best practices for addressing veteran homelessness. The Department of Veterans Affairs is creating the National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to integrate evidence-based practices, policies, and programs for homeless veterans and those at risk. It will also serve as a resource center for research and training activities related to veteran homelessness. The Department of Veterans Affairs is establishing the National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to improve grant and per diem programs. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2012 of title 38, United States Code to include a new subsection (e) for reviewing grant recipients and eligible entities' performance in assisting veterans with housing and increasing their income. The Department of Veterans Affairs is amending Section 2012 of title 38, United States Code to establish performance targets for grant recipients and eligible entities assisting veterans with housing and income. The Secretary will evaluate performance annually to determine continued per diem payments.
